I believe that the writer explained the Japanese custom of taking abandoned bikes very well. It was obviously a misunderstanding based on cultural differences. Nowhere was it mentioned that the Japanese, contrary to what we do, put signs on their furniture, TVs, bikes etc that they leave unlocked and unattended for days on the sidewalk. If I put a perfectly fine household or other item outside for neighbors or passers-bye to take home, I always label it "free", or "working".

Really?!? You took a shiny new looking bike thinking it was left for free taking? Bet that's what the went through the mind of the borrowers who took my last 8 shiny new looking bike, and also with a lock! Everyone should know that nothing is free for the taking, unless a sign tells you so.
That is our problem, we are always subjected to judgement by others. I have made my desires crystal clear to my children and I hope they do not suffer at the hands of others who may not agree.

There are indeed "fates worse than death", and one of them is the long, very slow decline from microvascular heart disease. This just happens to be primarily a women's disease, and was not recognized as a "real" heart disease until about 10 years ago. It's not dramatic; it quietly diminishes one's activities through fatigue, shortness of breath, and generally feeling lousy. Occasionally the associated unstable angina flares up, often in the middle of the night. Definitely not fun. Hard to tell who is more frustrated by not being able to do much of anything about the disease, me or my cardiologist. And impossible to answer the question, "How long?"

Sandy, I am very sorry you are experiencing this.  Actually, breathlessness is a question that looms large in my mind, because of several different family members.  One older family member wound up in the ICU after a cardiac "event," with severe breathlessness.  He was not a good candidate for open heart surgery, but on the other hand, he felt like he was suffocating. You can't endure suffocation like you can endure aching joints.  Something had to be done.  What?  What should an old, but still alive, person do in that situation?

What were your mother's chances of a successful operation?  You do not tell us, and therefore we cannot judge whether we agree or disagree.  It appears that doing nothing did not benefit your mother any,

Mr Leonard:

Have you spent much time recently at the bedside or caring for an actively dying person, a week or less before death?

For the most part they are utterly miserable. They likely will be heavily medicated and even so are often curled up in fetal positions. Mostly, their bodies have shut down...they cannot eat or even sip water
comfortably. Often their urine is backed up, their fecal matter hopelessly impacted. Their lips are cracked, their vascular systems slowed down causing all kinds of pain in the extremeties.

And yes, when we can, gentle touch, stroking, comforting words even a near presence can be good....but remember...much of that is for you and not for the person dying.

Mostly what dying people want is to die. So when we comfort and soothe and are witness and are there...wonderful. But keep it short, the dying person would say...and mercifully just let me go.

And no Molly, I don't need the business.  But to use your argument then doctors shouldn't treat any problem in patients in hospices be they infections, bed sores, or anything else as the patients are terminally ill.  I happen to believe that all people why they are alive have a right to be as pain free as possible. By the way a little thing called the Hippocratic Oath requires that of me.

Thank you for the laugh, Mr. Park. I wonder if you can give me some pointers on how to get my 86-year-old mother who is in hospice, with dementia, and in agony for the last 5 months, to speed things up? Ideal duration of dying would be seven days, huh? Best of luck to you.

Yes, slow dying might be better than instant death. Perhaps the ideal duration of dying would be seven days. We need time to make meaningful connections and disconnections, to say good-bye in the most meaningful possible ways by touching the people we love.

UNSUNG HEROES  Our cousin offered to write a biography of my wife's mother several years ago, as she had written some for both of her parents.  A gifted writer, she presented us with a lovely book that was shared with family members and has given us all a lot of enjoyment.  I think about 30 copies were printed with more available upon demand.  I'm going to see if it can be published on the Internet also.  At the time, my wife's mother was "with it," though now, at 94, she's frail and forgetful.  When we met with a social worker to see if she was eligible for a program in her apartment, I brought out the book and asked her to share it with anyone who was going to work with my wife's mother, because she's from the old school, is hard-wired for getting to know people and their families, and will not abide someone sitting down, getting out a clipboard or laptop and asking impersonal questions before establishing rapport.  Now with the option of free blogs online, everyone can publish their private memoirs.  I just had a 50th high school class reunion.  Our class president has established a website so we can all keep in touch with each other.  It's been a source of much enjoyment and sharing.  I'm glad that there are so many opportunities for people to share the legacies of their rich lives with family and friends now and with future generations who will know them from their writings or what has been written about them.

Dear Mr. Novak,

"Writing Books Very Few Will Read." I'm sorry, but isn't that the lot of nearly every writer that has ever lived?

Cordially,
S.A. Traina

While I support the rights of caregivers, I think it's possible the "story" has been simplified and exaggerated to make a point. And if the family was named we might learn that.

As someone said, where I live you cannot hire a qualified caregiver for kids for less than $15/hr. And all I know have at least 1 week paid vacation and weekends or 2 other days off. What they don't all get is taxes and social security paid. But many may not want it either as it reduces their take home pay.

Obviously we know what island nation.  It is a major industry for them to include doctoring in the US and nursing. The other strategy is to bring them over illegally and threaten to call immigration if they complain.  How about requiring Americans to be hired?

If between them the parents do not make enough money to support hiring a caregiver for the children, at a living wage, then one of the parents should stay home for a few years. This is a no-brainer. If you were dealing with a family which could not afford to pay an auto mechanic minimum wage, you would not support forcing mechanics to work for less, you would say, well, sell the car, you can't afford to have it.

I say this because we park the entire cost of childcare on the individual family. If we wish as a society to support two-worker families we should socialize childcare as many countries do, and pay for it collectively. There is no excuse for a system which exploits the childcare workers.

This thread being full of moralistic aspersions directed at the Greeks, one can only wonder why moral reprehension is not piled instead on primarily German banks, which made the loans that Greece cannot pay back, and which were bailed out by, primarily by German, taxpayers, rather than to let free-market consequences of reckless risk-taking take their course.

If you are going to hate the Greeks, the least you can do is hate the German banks for making loans they should not have made to Greece, hate the German government for bailing those banks out, and recognize that the war the German government is fighting is to prevent backlash from the German public, by squeezing Greece mercilessly, for bailing out the banks.
